conversation.text: Hi! What can I help you today?
I'd like to make profiteroles.
Do you have water, butter, salt and sugar? If you do, please put them in a saucepan.
evidence: Put the water, butter, salt, and sugar in a saucepan.

conversation.text: Yes, I have them. What's next?
Then heat until a boil. Remember to stir the mixture until the butter has melted.
evidence: Bring to a boil, stirring until the butter has melted

conversation.text: Should I use medium-high?
Sorry I don't know, but I guess medium-high is good.
Ok, what should I do then?
Then take the pan off the heat and leave it to cool for 2-3 minutes. Afterwards, you can add flour to the mixture and beat it with a spoon or whisk until everything comes together.
evidence: Add the flour to the butter mixture and beat with a wooden spoon or whisk until everything comes together.

conversation.text: Just did that. What next?
Then add eggs to the mixture.
Do I need to beat eggs before adding them? How many eggs should I add?
No, but you need to beat well eggs with a spoon or electric mixer after each addition. The number of eggs depends on how many servings you are preparing.
evidence: beating well with a wooden spoon or electric mixer after each addition

conversation.text: I see. I have mixed eggs well. What's next?
Prepare a baking sheet with parchment paper, and then transfer your mixture into a pastry bag.
evidence: Line a baking sheet with parchment paper, then transfer the warm mixture into a pastry bag

conversation.text: What is a pastry bag?
Pastry bag is a tool used for squeezing doughs, creams and other baking ingredients onto platters or baking sheets.
I don't have it. What should I do?
You can make a pastry bag with a freezer bag.
Ok, I'll try that after our chatting. Let's just move on.
Then pipe drops of pastry onto the baking sheet, about one inch apart.
evidence: Pipe approximately 18-22 drops of pastry onto the baking sheet, about one inch apart.

conversation.text: Sounds interesting. What's next?
Then moisten your hands with water and lightly press down the swirl at the top of each puff.
evidence: Moisten your finger with water and use it to lightly press down the swirl at the top of each puff.

conversation.text: Done. What should I do after?
Preheat your oven to 425 °F (218 °C). Then place the baking sheet into the oven.
evidence: Place the baking sheet in an oven preheated to 425 °F (218 °C).

conversation.text: How long should I bake?
You need to bake for 15-20 minutes.
I don't know if the puffs are ready... How can I check that?
Are they puffed and golden brown?
evidence: until they are puffed and golden brown

conversation.text: Yes, they are .
Then they're ready.
evidence: until they are puffed and golden brown.

conversation.text: Ok, what's next then?
Then prick each puff with a skewer and return to the oven to dry for about 3 minutes.
evidence: Prick each profiterole once with a skewer, then return to the oven to dry for about 3 minutes

conversation.text: Just did that. Can I take them off the oven now?
Yes, you can take them off the oven and cool them on a sheet of baking paper.
evidence: Prick each profiterole once with a skewer, then return to the oven to dry for about 3 minutes
Cool on a sheet of baking paper

conversation.text: They have cooled to the room temperature now. Can I eat them now?
Yes, please enjoy your profiteroles!

procedure.summary: Put the water, butter, salt, and sugar in a saucepan.
procedure.description: Bring to a boil, stirring until the butter has melted. Take the saucepan off of the heat and leave to cool slightly for 2-3 minutes.

Add the flour to the butter mixture and beat with a wooden spoon or whisk until everything comes together. Put the saucepan back on the heat and beat vigorously until everything is off the sides of the saucepan. The dough will lump together and there will be a film on the bottom of the pan.

Transfer the mixture to a large bowl or the bowl of a mixer. Add the eggs one at a time, beating well with a wooden spoon or electric mixer after each addition. It may seem like the mixture will not come back together, but don't worry, it will - just keep beating.

Line a baking sheet with parchment paper, then transfer the warm mixture into a pastry bag. Pipe approximately 18-22 drops of pastry onto the baking sheet, about one inch apart. The pastry drops should be about 1 ⁄4 inches (3.2 cm) wide and 1 inch (2.5 cm) high. If you do not have a pastry bag, you can use a spoon to place drops of pastry on the baking sheet.

Moisten your finger with water and use it to lightly press down the swirl at the top of each puff. At this point you can also brush the pastries with egg wash, if you would like them to be shiny after baking.

Place the baking sheet in an oven preheated to 425 °F (218 °C). Bake for 15-20 minutes until they are puffed and golden brown. Prick each profiterole once with a skewer, then return to the oven to dry for about 3 minutes, propping the oven door slightly ajar. Cool on a sheet of baking paper on a wire rack.
